lexUnit.name: rate.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: to evaluate something on a scale depending on some quality, esp. when the number of outcomes is limited "Travelers rated Japan Air Lines "Excellent" with regard to in-flight service."

sentence.text: People rated television the most useful source of information about party leaders and political issues , and the most helpful source for making up their minds how to vote .
Two testers rated Uvistat Factor 15 Cream ( £7.29 ) very highly , claiming it prevented the problem completely .
In a follow-up survey , the great majority rated it the best AIDS resource they had seen .
Eysenck claims that criminals tend to rate highly on two personality characteristics -- extroversion and neuroticism -- both of which he sees as being predominantly inherited .
AAA/Aaa rated banks in the world as rated by Standard & Poor 's and Moody 's
A BALLET lover yesterday lost her £200 damages claim over what she rated as a bad performance by superstar Rudolph Nureyev .
How do you rate your chances tomorrow ? "
How do you rate the performance of your cylinder cleaner ?
Independence does not rate highly with them , whereas their health does .
Philistus was rated high in antiquity , but forty-one of the seventy-seven surviving quotations are all from the same late geographical dictionary .
In 1601 the average had fallen still further , to £311 , while only one family was rated above £1,000 and the highest income was £2,226 .
He did not rate his findings on the antibacterial substance worthy of a full paper , and included them in a publication which dealt with several substances derived from Penicillia .
Current champion Michael Roberts is rated second favourite
